title: How to make cayenne powder
description: When you grow cayenne peppers, you have to make your own cayenne powder! Here's how we like to replenish our spice rack with delicious, smoky, spicy pepper powder. We use a simple food dehydrator and a spice grinder to achieve a perfect, fine powder. You could also use your oven to make your own cayenne, but the temperature should be low (around 125¬∞F). #spicyfood #spices #gardeningtips

title: Jalape√±o hot sauce recipe #recipeshorts #hotsauce
description:
Fresh jalapeno peppers are perfect for making delicious hot sauce from scratch. This easy hot sauce recipe uses green jalape√±os, onion, garlic, and a few other tasty ingredients. It's perfect for tacos, eggs, or as a sandwich spread. The heat level is medium-low (depending on how spicy your jalapenos are), and it can last for a month or so in the fridge.

Ingredients:
1/2 lb jalape√±o peppers (about 6)
1/2 onion
2 cloves garlic
2/3 cup white vinegar
1 tsp sugar
1 tsp salt
10 sprigs cilantro
1/2 tsp cumin
1 cup water
Oil (for searing)

Full recipe:
https://peppergeek.com/jalapeno-hot-sauce-recipe

title: Crunchy quick pickled jalape√±os #recipeshorts
description:
Pickled jalapenos are so easy to make. Use green peppers for the best *crunch* factor, and the fresher the harvest, the better. I like using these quick-pickles on sandwiches, cheese and crackers, omelets, burgers, and even pizza. They add a zing of flavor and spiciness that is easy to crave. Plus, this is technically a way to preserve peppers for at least 3 months in the fridge!

Ingredients:
10-12 jalape√±os
1-2 cloves garlic
1 tsp dried oregano
2 cups white vinegar
1 cup water
1 tbsp salt
1 tbsp sugar

#recipeoftheday #recipeshare #pickles

title: Making my own chipotles was definitely worth it
description: Chipotle peppers are smoked and dried red jalape√±os. That's it. I use a kamado-style smoker grill to smoke the red jalapeno peppers for at least 2-3 hours. The temperature needs to be very low to avoid cooking the peppers, ideally around 160¬∞F or so. After smoking, all that's left is to dehydrate the peppers into dried chipotles. These smoky peppers are a flavorful addition to spice blends, rubs, and soups and stews. Yum!

description:

Hope you try this spicy jam recipe for yourself and see what you think.

***************************************
Recipe:

Ingredients:
10 oz frozen strawberries
2 jalape√±o peppers, diced
3/4 cup sugar
2 tbsp lemon juice

Steps:
1. Thaw strawberries over medium heat, stirring regularly.
2. Once soft, mash strawberries to desired consistency.
3. Add all other ingredients and stir to dissolve sugar.
4. Simmer for 20-30 minutes until temperature reaches 220¬∞F (104¬∞C)
5. Remove from heat and skim off surface foam (optional)
6. Add to jars and allow to cool for at least an hour at room temp. Then, store in fridge for 2-3 weeks.

Optional: Water bath can the filled jars and store at room temperature for 1 year.

title: Spicy Lollipops - How to Make Spicy Hard Candy - Pepper Geek
description:
Today, we're making spicy hot pepper lollipops! These are a fun treat for anyone who likes everything spicy. They're also super easy and quick to make, though it can get a bit messy.

*Be very careful with the hot candy!

***************************************
Ingredients:
- 1 Cup Sugar
- 1/4 Cup Light Corn Syrup
- 1/4 Cup Water 
- 1/2 tsp Hot Pepper Powder
- 1/2 Flavored Candy Oil

Directions:
1. Mix sugar, corn syrup, and water in a saucepan on medium-high heat. Stir well until everything is combined.
2. The mixture will begin bubbling, do not stir again after this point.
3. Monitor temperature very closely using a candy thermometer. As soon as the temperature reaches 300¬∞F (150¬∞C), remove the saucepan from the stove.
4. Stir in hot pepper powder and flavored oil to the mixture. Carefully pour into the molds.
5. Allow to cool for at least an hour. Cool for longer if packaging.

***************************************

title: Sweet Chili Sauce Recipe - A Sweet & Spicy Delight - Pepper Geek
description:
Sweet chili sauce is a fantastic, sweet and spicy dipping sauce. It is perfect for spring rolls, potstickers, rice, shrimp or even chicken wings. The best part is how simple it is to make - basically a quick, 1-pot sauce that takes about 15 minutes!

Instagram:
https://instagram.com/peppergeek

Printable recipe:
https://peppergeek.com/homemade-sweet-chili-sauce-thai-peppers

***********************************
RECIPE (Makes 6-8 oz of chili sauce) 

Sweet chili sauce ingredients:
- 5-7 Thai peppers (~2 tbsp), finely chopped
- 1-2 cloves garlic (~1 tbsp), finely chopped
- 1/4 cup rice vinegar
- 1/2 cup water
- 1/2 cup sugar
- 3/4 tsp salt

Cornstarch slurry ingredients:
- 1/2 tbsp corn starch
- 1 tbsp cold water

Directions:
- Mix all ingredients except cornstarch slurry in a medium pot
- Bring to a boil, then reduce heat
- Simmer 4-5 minutes, stirring occasionally
- Mix cold water and corn starch in small bowl, then pour into pot
- Stir immediately and simmer for another 3-4 minutes
- Remove from heat and allow to cool
- Pour sauce into glass jar and refrigerate

description:

Sunscald is one of the most common issues pepper growers face. It comes from inadequate hardening off, and is hard to avoid completely. This is essentially a sunburn on the leaves of your plants, and can affect many other types of vegetable plant foliage.

Sunscald can also affect pepper fruits if they are exposed to direct sunlight. The pepper's flesh can become burned, leading to white spots that eventually rot.

title: Bottom Pruning and Mulching Pepper Plants - Pepper Geek
description:
Get our eBook!
‚ñ∫‚ñ∫ https://peppergeek.com/ebook

In this video, we discuss the benefits of mulching and bottom pruning pepper plants. These two techniques are great for creating an easier-to-manage pepper garden that is also more attractive.

Mulching peppers is a great way to prevent weeds, reduce soil splashing and insulating the roots from the cold. We love using straw, but it can be a bit messy. You can also use grass clippings, black plastic, or wood chips (though you should use some caution with these).

Bottom pruning is optional, but definitely worth considering for its benefits. The goal is to remove lower foliage (but not low branches) from the plant, up to about 6" above the soil. This helps avoid soil hitting the leaves, and makes it much easier to access the plant for watering and harvesting.

title: Staking  Pepper Plants - How To Support Peppers - Pepper Geek
description:
Staking peppers is important to prevent wind damage. As the pepper plants grow taller, they become more susceptible to strong winds. Broken branches and even knocked over plants are possible if you don't provide a sturdy stake.

Also, attaching the plant to the stake at multiple points is important to ensure that each part of the plant has the support it needs. As your plants begin to fruit, the peppers can weigh on the branches, potentially causing damage if left unsupported.

So in this video, we show our simple method for staking peppers and discuss the various pepper species and how they need to be supported.

Chinense peppers require the most support, especially when grown in large pots. They can be huge and bushy with many large branches, benefiting from a tomato-cage-like support system.

Annuum peppers usually need just one central stake, while baccatum and pubescens grow tall and slender, requiring a tall, central stake for support.

title: Root Bound Peppers - How To Avoid Root Bound Plants - Pepper Geek
description:
In today's video, we're discussing root bound plants. When your peppers (or other plant varieties) become root bound, the root system essentially begins to tangle. The roots run out of room in their pots and begin to travel back up in search of more growing media.

This is a very common issue, especially when your peppers are planted too early or are otherwise left in small containers for too long. We'll cover why root bound plants happy, how to avoid it in the future, and how to correct the problem.

title: The 'Aloha' Pepper is Literally One of a Kind - Pepper Geek
description:
In this video, I discuss the Aloha pepper or the Enjoya pepper variety. These peppers are gorgeous..and have an interesting origin story. If you're hoping to grow your own red/yellow striped bell peppers, think again.

The peppers were grown during a "screening trial of mutants" of a pepper variety. The result is a plant that is being repeatedly cloned to produce more of the striped peppers. In other words, all of these peppers (likely) come from a single organism!

In any case, this pepper is COOL. I wish we could crossbreed the striped pattern into other Capsicum annuum varieties, but alas, we (probably) cannot.

UPDATE: We tasted this pepper and it is DELICIOUS. Sweet and crunchy, like a yellow bell pepper.

DISCLAIMER: I don't actually know how this pepper was created, we're just speculating for the most part! It is interesting that the seeds don't produce true-to-form pepper pods when grown, but the exact process used to achieve this variety is unknown.

Read more:
https://the-biologist-is-in.blogspot.com/2017/02/biology-of-enjoya-pepper.html

Hope you enjoy :)

#peppers #gardening #aloha #enjoya

title: Simple, Spicy Guacamole Recipe with Fresh Jalape√±os - Pepper Geek
description:
Learn how to make guacamole with our simple and spicy guacamole recipe! This tasty appetizer is fresh, crunchy and satisfying. It is great to eat on corn chips, or spread over toast for a tasty breakfast. We love using fresh peppers from our harvest for this recipe.

This guacamole is a great Cinco De Mayo recipe, or for any time of the year really! It is a delicious appetizer or snack to enjoy fresh for up to 2-3 days when refrigerated.

Recipe:
2 ripe avocados
1/2 large white or yellow onion (diced)
1/2 large tomato 
1-2 peppers (jalapeno or serrano)
1 large lime juiced (approx 1 ounce)
1-2 cloves garlic (finely chopped)
1 tsp fresh cilantro
1/2 tsp cumin
1/4 tsp cayenne pepper
1/4 tsp sea salt 

Mix all ingredients in a large bowl, add avocado last, and mash together. Enjoy!

title: Should You Pick Early Pepper Flowers?
description:
Join our Patreon and grow with us!
https://www.patreon.com/peppergeek

In this video, I answer a common question for pepper growers: Should I pick early pepper flower buds? It is typical to see early flowers blooming on young, indoor pepper plants. The plants are entering the fruiting stage, but isn't it a bit early for them to produce peppers?

Pepper Geek Shirts:
https://www.etsy.com/shop/peppergeek

Read more about pruning pepper flowers:
https://peppergeek.com/pinching-off-pepper-plant-flowers/

***********************************************
In This Video:
0:00 - Intro
0:56 - Should you pick pepper flowers
2:02 - How to prune pepper flowers
2:58 - When to STOP picking pepper flowers
3:51 - When NOT to pick pepper flowers

***********************************************
Pruning or cutting pepper flowers is a great way to increase pepper yields in the long run. As long as your growing season is long enough, you should cut any early flower buds to encourage the plants to grow more leaves and branches. Once the plants have been outdoors for 2-4 weeks, you can stop cutting off flowers and allow them to produce fruits.

Thanks for watching!

title: Pruning Pepper Plants - How To Prune Peppers For Bigger Harvests - Pepper Geek
description:
Get our eBook, Growing Perfect Peppers!
‚ñ∫‚ñ∫ https://peppergeek.com/ebook

DISCLAIMER: We no longer prune our pepper plants! Learn why in this video:
‚ñ∫‚ñ∫ https://youtu.be/j1eWBIfhR3A

In this video, we share a simple method for pruning pepper plants. The idea is that, by pruning, you help build a stronger stem, a bushier plant, and perhaps a larger harvest. Here is how to prune pepper plants early in the season.

While topping your peppers is an option, we no longer prune our plants. The reason is that we have seen little overall gain in terms of yield, so we don't bother anymore!

************************************************
Read more about pruning:
https://peppergeek.com/pruning-pepper-plants

************************************************
More pepper plant pruning tips:
- Use sharp scissors or pruning shears
- Don't prune too late in the season
- Don't fertilize right after pruning (wait a week or so)

I hope this helps and thanks for watching Pepper Geek!
